title: ODVerse33: Is the New YOLO Version Always Better? A Multi Domain benchmark from YOLO v5 to v11
author: Tianyou Jiang (College of Information Science and Engineering, Shandong Agricultural University), Yang Zhong (College of Information Science and Engineering, Shandong Agricultural University)
relevance_why: The paper presents a benchmark across various domains, which could inform the development of computer vision models in audio and multimedia applications, enhancing my understanding of model performance in diverse contexts.
background: The study evaluates the performance of multiple YOLO (You Only Look Once) object detection models across different tasks in various domains to understand their real-world applicability.
contribution: ODVerse33 introduces a comprehensive benchmark of 33 datasets across 11 domains to analyze YOLO models, aiming to determine if newer YOLO versions consistently outperform their predecessors.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous evaluations often focused solely on COCO data, limiting the understanding of cross-domain performance.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work broadens the evaluation scope and systematically compares models from YOLOv5 to YOLOv11 across multiple real-world datasets.

key_innovation: The introduction of the ODverse33 benchmark allows for a more nuanced analysis of YOLO models' performance in diverse conditions, highlighting the necessity of model selection based on specific application requirements.
real_world_impact: This benchmark can guide practitioners in selecting appropriate YOLO models for their specific tasks, ultimately improving the application of object detection in various fields such as agriculture, medicine, and security.

new_terms.mean average precision (mAP): **Mean Average Precision (mAP)** is a metric used to evaluate the accuracy of object detection models by measuring the average precision across different recall levels.
new_terms.Intersection over Union (IoU): **Intersection over Union (IoU)** is a performance metric that quantifies the overlap between the predicted bounding box and the ground truth bounding box.
